**Transcript**:
Pharaoh Ramesses II reigned
for almost 70 years in the 13th century BCE. He presided over a golden age
of Egyptian prosperity. But was he a model leader, or a shameless egomaniac
and master of propaganda? Order! Order! Who do we have on the stand?
Ramesses II? Ahem, I believe you mean
"The strong bull, protector of Egypt, who subdues foreign lands; rich in years, great in victories,
chosen by Ra— whose justice is powerful— Ramesses, beloved of Amun." But you may refer to him
as Ramesses the Great. Ramesses, Ramesses— 
I think I've heard of him. "Let my people go!" Yes, Your Honor, he was the infamously
stubborn pharaoh of Exodus, who forced enslaved Hebrews to build out his extravagant capital city
of Pi-Ramesses. Objection, there's no
archaeological evidence that Ramesses used forced labor
in his construction projects. Egyptians relied on highly trained
artisans and craftsmen to build their cities and monuments. And menial labor,
like quarrying and moving stones, was done by military soldiers
and foreign mercenaries— all of whom were compensated
for their work. So he's not the pharaoh from Exodus? It's hard to say for certain. According to some timelines, Ramesses is the best candidate
for that particular pharaoh. But there's no evidence of any Hebrew
population in Egypt during his reign, and certainly no records of a revolution
or mass migration like the one described in Exodus. Is that really so surprising? It's not like Ramesses kept records
of any other time he was defeated. What do you mean? Our "great" pharaoh here operated
one of the largest propaganda machines in ancient history. Almost all pharaohs relied on propaganda
to control their country, and Ramesses had particularly
big sandals to fill. His father, Seti I, led Egypt to a period
of great wealth and stability that Ramesses worked hard to maintain. Through propaganda, yes,
but also military glory. More like military aggression. By the end of Seti's reign, he had established peace
with the neighboring Hittites by guaranteeing Egyptian control
over a sought-after region called Kadesh. But in the fifth year of his reign,
Ramesses broke those agreements. It wasn't the most peaceful decision, but Ramesses believed a military victory
would aid his efforts to restore Egypt's reputation. And he was right! His victory over the Hittites
cemented Ramesses' persona as a heroic pharaoh of old. Yeah, except he didn't even win! His supposed victory was
actually a stalemate in which the pharaoh's arrogance
almost cost Egypt the entire war. When two Hittite spies told Ramesses
the enemy had fled in fear, he let his guard down,
allowing his men to be ambushed. He played right into the Hittite's trap
and almost lost everything. Yet the official story Ramesses
had chiseled across Egypt cast himself as the battle's
greatest hero. Military achievements were important
for legitimizing a pharaoh's power, even if that meant a bit
of exaggeration. A bit? You can't trust
anything this guy says! If it wasn't for the Hittite's
conflicting record, we'd still be buying Ramesses' propaganda. I propose that this court cannot judge
any historical figure's legacy by the stories they tell about themselves. That seems reasonable to me. Fair enough. How's this record then— the first recorded peace treaty
in archaeological history signed by Ramesses and the Hittites. "Peace treaty" is pretty generous. Ramesses begrudgingly agreed
to a mutual defense contract, where Egyptians and Hittites would work
together if attacked by an external enemy. And what's wrong with that? This peaceful end to the conflict
marked the beginning of Ramesses' prosperous reign— a golden age of Egyptian power and wealth. True, but we have no idea if this wealth
trickled down to everyday Egyptians or just financed Ramesses' vain attempts
to achieve immortality through stone. He spent his entire reign pouring
money into ego projects. And one of the most famous,
Abu Simbel, wasn't even in Egypt! Abu Simbel was in Nubia to showcase
Egypt's strength and discourage a Nubian revolution. Besides, pharaohs were expected to invest
in building projects for the gods. Right, "for the gods,"
which Ramesses was not. Pharaohs typically occupied a status
between gods and mortals, but the location of Ramesses' statue
inside Abu Simbel positions him as their supposed equal. He even tore down existing temples
to reuse their bricks in monuments to himself! He tore down temples built by Akhenaten, a pharaoh who'd attempted
to impose monotheism. By destroying those temples, Ramesses reinforced his commitment
to Egypt's traditional religion. That doesn't account for why he frequently
erased other pharaohs' names on monuments and replaced them with his own. Hey, what the...? Even pharaohs who had short reigns
had numerous statues made of themselves— and Ramesses ruled
for almost seven decades. Well, he definitely made
a lasting impression. Let's face it, Your Honor, would we even
be talking about him today if he hadn't? It's often said that history is written
by the winners, but in this courtroom, a winning record never guarantees
the outcome.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Ramesses II fought the Hittites in the famed Battle of ____.
Options: A. Gaza, B. Hattuša, C. Memphis, D. Kadesh
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the official Egyptian record of Pharaoh Ramesses II? Options: A. The strong bull, protector of Egypt, who subdues foreign lands, B. A master of propaganda and egomaniac, C. The pharaoh who forced enslaved Hebrews to build out his extravagant capital city of Pi-Ramesses, D. The pharaoh who broke agreements with the Hittites Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the primary source of labor for construction projects in ancient Egypt? Options: A. Forced labor of enslaved Hebrews, B. Highly trained artisans and craftsmen, C. Military soldiers and foreign mercenaries, D. Slaves from other countries Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what was the significance of the Hittite spies' message to Ramesses? Options: A. It led to a decisive victory for the Egyptians, B. It led to a stalemate in the war, C. It resulted in the death of Ramesses, D. It led to a treaty between the Egyptians and Hittites Correct Option: B

A decisive victory for the Egyptians, C. A loss for the Egyptians, D. A mutual defense contract between the Egyptians and Hittites Correct Option: B

It led to a war between the Egyptians and Hittites, C. It resulted in the death of Ramesses, D. It marked a peaceful end to the conflict Correct Option: D
Question 6: What was the purpose of the Abu Simbel monument, according to the transcript? Options: A. To showcase Egypt's strength and discourage a Nubian revolution, B. To commemorate the victory of the Egyptians over the Hittites, C. To honor the gods of Egypt, D. To celebrate the life of Ramesses Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the reaction of the courtroom to Ramesses' propaganda? Options: A. They believed everything he said, B. They were skeptical of his claims, C. They were impressed by his achievements, D. They were indifferent to his legacy Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the outcome of the court's discussion about Ramesses' legacy? Options: A. They concluded that he was a great pharaoh, B. They decided that his legacy was questionable, C. They ruled that he was a bad pharaoh, D. They were unable to reach a verdict Correct Option: B

Question 10: What does the transcript suggest about the nature of history and historical records? Options: A. That history is always objective and truthful, B. That history is often subjective and biased, C. That historical records are always accurate and reliable, D. That historical records are often incomplete and inaccurate Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Pharaoh Ramesses II reigned
for almost 70 years in the 13th century BCE. He presided over a golden age
of Egyptian prosperity. But was he a model leader, or a shameless egomaniac
and master of propaganda? Order! Order! Who do we have on the stand?
Ramesses II? Ahem, I believe you mean
"The strong bull, protector of Egypt, who subdues foreign lands; rich in years, great in victories,
chosen by Ra— whose justice is powerful— Ramesses, beloved of Amun." But you may refer to him
as Ramesses the Great. Ramesses, Ramesses— 
I think I've heard of him. "Let my people go!" Yes, Your Honor, he was the infamously
stubborn pharaoh of Exodus, who forced enslaved Hebrews to build out his extravagant capital city
of Pi-Ramesses. Objection, there's no
archaeological evidence that Ramesses used forced labor
in his construction projects. Egyptians relied on highly trained
artisans and craftsmen to build their cities and monuments. And menial labor,
like quarrying and moving stones, was done by military soldiers
and foreign mercenaries— all of whom were compensated
for their work. So he's not the pharaoh from Exodus? It's hard to say for certain. According to some timelines, Ramesses is the best candidate
for that particular pharaoh. But there's no evidence of any Hebrew
population in Egypt during his reign, and certainly no records of a revolution
or mass migration like the one described in Exodus. Is that really so surprising? It's not like Ramesses kept records
of any other time he was defeated. What do you mean? Our "great" pharaoh here operated
one of the largest propaganda machines in ancient history. Almost all pharaohs relied on propaganda
to control their country, and Ramesses had particularly
big sandals to fill. His father, Seti I, led Egypt to a period
of great wealth and stability that Ramesses worked hard to maintain. Through propaganda, yes,
but also military glory. More like military aggression. By the end of Seti's reign, he had established peace
with the neighboring Hittites by guaranteeing Egyptian control
over a sought-after region called Kadesh. But in the fifth year of his reign,
Ramesses broke those agreements. It wasn't the most peaceful decision, but Ramesses believed a military victory
would aid his efforts to restore Egypt's reputation. And he was right! His victory over the Hittites
cemented Ramesses' persona as a heroic pharaoh of old. Yeah, except he didn't even win! His supposed victory was
actually a stalemate in which the pharaoh's arrogance
almost cost Egypt the entire war. When two Hittite spies told Ramesses
the enemy had fled in fear, he let his guard down,
allowing his men to be ambushed. He played right into the Hittite's trap
and almost lost everything. Yet the official story Ramesses
had chiseled across Egypt cast himself as the battle's
greatest hero. Military achievements were important
for legitimizing a pharaoh's power, even if that meant a bit
of exaggeration. A bit? You can't trust
anything this guy says! If it wasn't for the Hittite's
conflicting record, we'd still be buying Ramesses' propaganda. I propose that this court cannot judge
any historical figure's legacy by the stories they tell about themselves. That seems reasonable to me. Fair enough. How's this record then— the first recorded peace treaty
in archaeological history signed by Ramesses and the Hittites. "Peace treaty" is pretty generous. Ramesses begrudgingly agreed
to a mutual defense contract, where Egyptians and Hittites would work
together if attacked by an external enemy. And what's wrong with that? This peaceful end to the conflict
marked the beginning of Ramesses' prosperous reign— a golden age of Egyptian power and wealth. True, but we have no idea if this wealth
trickled down to everyday Egyptians or just financed Ramesses' vain attempts
to achieve immortality through stone. He spent his entire reign pouring
money into ego projects. And one of the most famous,
Abu Simbel, wasn't even in Egypt! Abu Simbel was in Nubia to showcase
Egypt's strength and discourage a Nubian revolution. Besides, pharaohs were expected to invest
in building projects for the gods. Right, "for the gods,"
which Ramesses was not. Pharaohs typically occupied a status
between gods and mortals, but the location of Ramesses' statue
inside Abu Simbel positions him as their supposed equal. He even tore down existing temples
to reuse their bricks in monuments to himself! He tore down temples built by Akhenaten, a pharaoh who'd attempted
to impose monotheism. By destroying those temples, Ramesses reinforced his commitment
to Egypt's traditional religion. That doesn't account for why he frequently
erased other pharaohs' names on monuments and replaced them with his own. Hey, what the...? Even pharaohs who had short reigns
had numerous statues made of themselves— and Ramesses ruled
for almost seven decades. Well, he definitely made
a lasting impression. Let's face it, Your Honor, would we even
be talking about him today if he hadn't? It's often said that history is written
by the winners, but in this courtroom, a winning record never guarantees
the outcome.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Ramesses II built a famous temple at Abu Simbel in Nubia, which features four huge statues of himself on the façade and is important because ____.
Options: A. It uses a new building technique, B. It celebrates a new monotheistic religion, C. It shows Ramesses II as equal to the gods, D. It is the biggest temple ever built
Correct Option: C

for almost 70 years in the 13th century BCE. He presided over a golden age
of Egyptian prosperity. But was he a model leader, or a shameless egomaniac
and master of propaganda? Order! Order! Who do we have on the stand?
Ramesses II? Ahem, I believe you mean
"The strong bull, protector of Egypt, who subdues foreign lands; rich in years, great in victories,
chosen by Ra— whose justice is powerful— Ramesses, beloved of Amun." But you may refer to him
as Ramesses the Great. Ramesses, Ramesses—

stubborn pharaoh of Exodus, who forced enslaved Hebrews to build out his extravagant capital city
of Pi-Ramesses. Objection, there's no
archaeological evidence that Ramesses used forced labor
in his construction projects. Egyptians relied on highly trained

for their work. So he's not the pharaoh from Exodus? It's hard to say for certain. According to some timelines, Ramesses is the best candidate

or mass migration like the one described in Exodus. Is that really so surprising? It's not like Ramesses kept records

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Battle of Kadesh ended in a stalemate but is important for leading to the world’s first recorded ____.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Surveying his vast domain, 
trident heavy in hand, Poseidon considers 
the prospect of retirement. What if someone else donned
the coral crown so he could spend his immortality
harmonizing with blue whales and cozying up to hydrothermal vents? Poseidon decides he needs to actually
prioritize himself for once. So he summons his accountant and asks: how much could he sell
the ocean for today? Poseidon’s accountant is the
top-ranked financial analyst to the world’s movers and shakers, its literal titans of industry. He handles all divine assets. When it comes to boiling complex systems
of intrinsic value down to monetary sums, he’s the guy. And he’s actually got a potential buyer: Hades is interested in building
his real estate portfolio and expanding his domain
into the marine realm. So, the accountant already appraised
the ocean’s market value and prepared a quick presentation. "The property covers
over 70% of Earth’s surface. But it’s also quite voluminous!" Poseidon knows this. He does annual Mariana Trench
swims with sea cucumbers. But before he even gets
to his best giant squid story, the accountant is back at analysis. "Marine shipping alone accounts
for 80% of global trade, generating over $14 trillion annually. The global fishing industry 
provides over 3 billion people with a significant amount 
of their dietary protein, employs an estimated 260 million, and generates about $163 billion
every year. And oil and budding
seabed mining industries generate around $245 billion per year." "Some of the ocean’s assets
are harder to quantify monetarily. The ocean absorbs around 30%
of human generated carbon dioxide, and, since 1955, has taken
in more than 90% of excess heat. About 40% of humanity lives
within 100 kilometers of the ocean. Coastal ecosystems buffer waves,
reduce erosion, and ease flooding, preventing over $716 billion
in damages annually. Many cultures have deep ties to the ocean. And coastal views and recreation
improve mental health. Meanwhile, it's estimated
that as-yet undiscovered marine-derived cancer treatments
could save countless lives and be worth up to $5.7 trillion. The ocean generates half
the planet’s oxygen and, directly or indirectly, provides food, energy, and minerals
to all life on Earth." A salty tear cascades down Poseidon’s face
that the accountant ignores. He can’t give the total cost yet
because, of course, recent developments must be factored in. "Climate change is heating, acidifying,
and deoxygenating the ocean and trash is polluting it. Overfishing and aggressive 
seabed resource extraction are disrupting fragile ecosystems
and impacting the ocean’s productivity." The accountant says, "Sigh, buddy,
you shouldn’t worry, though, because we can grow
the ocean’s investment value. Coral reef tourism already yields
approximately $36 billion annually. Considering the revenue
of popular dive sites and their regional shark
populations and lifespans, researchers estimate that one shark can
generate almost $2 million in its lifetime— making them much more valuable
alive than dead. Sustainable management of fisheries
could allow species to rebound and bring in an additional
$83 billion annually. And with growth in offshore wind, 
tidal, and wave energy harvesting, the ocean is poised to help
humanity quit fossil fuels." Now the grand reveal. The accountant's conclusions are similar
to those of mortal experts: the ocean alone is worth
roughly $24 trillion— at least— about a quarter
of the World Bank’s valuation of the global economy in 2021. But if humanity reinvests
in the ocean's health— fishing sustainably,
decarbonizing shipping, scaling offshore wind farms,
and conserving and restoring mangroves— investments could return
up to 600% in profits. Poseidon feels the weight of his folly
crushing him like a Styrofoam cup 2,000 meters deep. Reducing such a priceless, generously
life-giving natural system to a number is just another symptom of the greatest
problems he’s facing nowadays. And though he respects the work
his brother, Hades, does, he doesn't want the ocean to become
an extension of the Underworld. He can’t give it up. Poseidon asks forgiveness and reaffirms his eternal vow
to protect the ocean. It’ll take him a few tidal cycles
to realize Hades and the accountant were bluffing 
and see what this really was: a much-needed intervention by a duo
of deities who cared deeply about him— and the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Maritime shipping accounts for ____ of global trade.
Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80%
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason Poseidon wants to sell the ocean? Options: A. To expand his domain into the marine realm and quit fossil fuels, B. To prioritize himself for once and spend his immortality harmonizing with blue whales, C. To make money from coral reef tourism and expand his domain into the marine realm, D. To focus on protecting the ocean and its inhabitants Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what percentage of global trade is generated by marine shipping? Options: A. 60%, B. 70%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the estimated value of undiscovered marine-derived cancer treatments? Options: A. $5 trillion, B. $5.7 trillion, C. $10 trillion, D. $15 trillion Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary concern of Poseidon's accountant when appraising the ocean's market value? Options: A. Climate change and pollution, B. Overfishing and aggressive seabed resource extraction, C. Boiling complex systems of intrinsic value down to monetary sums, D. The ocean's health and well-being Correct Option: C
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the estimated annual revenue of sustainable management of fisheries? Options: A. $50 billion, B. $83 billion, C. $100 billion, D. $150 billion Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the estimated value of the ocean alone, according to the accountant's conclusions? Options: A. $10 trillion, B. $15 trillion, C. $20 trillion, D. $24 trillion Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the primary goal of Hades in wanting to buy the ocean? Options: A. To expand his domain into the terrestrial realm, B. To build his real estate portfolio and expand his domain into the marine realm, C. To invest in coral reef tourism, D. To quit fossil fuels Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the estimated annual revenue of coral reef tourism? Options: A. $20 billion, B. $30 billion, C. $36 billion, D. $50 billion Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the estimated value of one shark in its lifetime, according to researchers? Options: A. $1 million, B. $1.5 million, C. $1.8 million, D. $2 million Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the estimated return on investment if humanity reinvests in the ocean's health? Options: A. 100%, B. 200%, C. 300%, D. 600% Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the percentage of global trade accounted for by marine shipping. The options and content of Question 2 are also similar to the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option being 80% in both cases.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Surveying his vast domain, 
trident heavy in hand, Poseidon considers 
the prospect of retirement. What if someone else donned
the coral crown so he could spend his immortality
harmonizing with blue whales and cozying up to hydrothermal vents? Poseidon decides he needs to actually
prioritize himself for once. So he summons his accountant and asks: how much could he sell
the ocean for today? Poseidon’s accountant is the
top-ranked financial analyst to the world’s movers and shakers, its literal titans of industry. He handles all divine assets. When it comes to boiling complex systems
of intrinsic value down to monetary sums, he’s the guy. And he’s actually got a potential buyer: Hades is interested in building
his real estate portfolio and expanding his domain
into the marine realm. So, the accountant already appraised
the ocean’s market value and prepared a quick presentation. "The property covers
over 70% of Earth’s surface. But it’s also quite voluminous!" Poseidon knows this. He does annual Mariana Trench
swims with sea cucumbers. But before he even gets
to his best giant squid story, the accountant is back at analysis. "Marine shipping alone accounts
for 80% of global trade, generating over $14 trillion annually. The global fishing industry 
provides over 3 billion people with a significant amount 
of their dietary protein, employs an estimated 260 million, and generates about $163 billion
every year. And oil and budding
seabed mining industries generate around $245 billion per year." "Some of the ocean’s assets
are harder to quantify monetarily. The ocean absorbs around 30%
of human generated carbon dioxide, and, since 1955, has taken
in more than 90% of excess heat. About 40% of humanity lives
within 100 kilometers of the ocean. Coastal ecosystems buffer waves,
reduce erosion, and ease flooding, preventing over $716 billion
in damages annually. Many cultures have deep ties to the ocean. And coastal views and recreation
improve mental health. Meanwhile, it's estimated
that as-yet undiscovered marine-derived cancer treatments
could save countless lives and be worth up to $5.7 trillion. The ocean generates half
the planet’s oxygen and, directly or indirectly, provides food, energy, and minerals
to all life on Earth." A salty tear cascades down Poseidon’s face
that the accountant ignores. He can’t give the total cost yet
because, of course, recent developments must be factored in. "Climate change is heating, acidifying,
and deoxygenating the ocean and trash is polluting it. Overfishing and aggressive 
seabed resource extraction are disrupting fragile ecosystems
and impacting the ocean’s productivity." The accountant says, "Sigh, buddy,
you shouldn’t worry, though, because we can grow
the ocean’s investment value. Coral reef tourism already yields
approximately $36 billion annually. Considering the revenue
of popular dive sites and their regional shark
populations and lifespans, researchers estimate that one shark can
generate almost $2 million in its lifetime— making them much more valuable
alive than dead. Sustainable management of fisheries
could allow species to rebound and bring in an additional
$83 billion annually. And with growth in offshore wind, 
tidal, and wave energy harvesting, the ocean is poised to help
humanity quit fossil fuels." Now the grand reveal. The accountant's conclusions are similar
to those of mortal experts: the ocean alone is worth
roughly $24 trillion— at least— about a quarter
of the World Bank’s valuation of the global economy in 2021. But if humanity reinvests
in the ocean's health— fishing sustainably,
decarbonizing shipping, scaling offshore wind farms,
and conserving and restoring mangroves— investments could return
up to 600% in profits. Poseidon feels the weight of his folly
crushing him like a Styrofoam cup 2,000 meters deep. Reducing such a priceless, generously
life-giving natural system to a number is just another symptom of the greatest
problems he’s facing nowadays. And though he respects the work
his brother, Hades, does, he doesn't want the ocean to become
an extension of the Underworld. He can’t give it up. Poseidon asks forgiveness and reaffirms his eternal vow
to protect the ocean. It’ll take him a few tidal cycles
to realize Hades and the accountant were bluffing 
and see what this really was: a much-needed intervention by a duo
of deities who cared deeply about him— and the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is not listed as a major threat to the ocean?
Options: A. Climate change, B. Pollution, C. Tourism, D. Overfishing
Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

However, since Question 4 does not match the ground truth MCQ's intent of identifying a "major threat to the ocean," I re-examined the generated MCQs and found that none of them directly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the topic of threats to the ocean, I would suggest Question 4, but with a note that it does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. and see what this really was: a much-needed intervention by a duo
of deities who cared deeply about him— and the world.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

to protect the ocean. It’ll take him a few tidal cycles
to realize Hades and the accountant were bluffing 
and see what this really was: a much-needed intervention by a duo
of deities who cared deeply about him— and the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The ocean absorbs around ___ of human-generated carbon dioxide and has taken in more than ___ of excess heat.
Options: A. 50%, 90%, B. 30%, 90%, C. 90%, 50%, D. 50%, 30%
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason Poseidon wants to sell the ocean? Options: A. To expand his domain into the marine realm and quit fossil fuels, B. To prioritize himself for once and spend his immortality harmonizing with blue whales, C. To make money from coral reef tourism and expand his domain into the marine realm, D. To focus on protecting the ocean and its inhabitants Correct Option: B

Overfishing and aggressive seabed resource extraction, C. Boiling complex systems of intrinsic value down to monetary sums, D. The ocean's health and well-being Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Surveying his vast domain, 
trident heavy in hand, Poseidon considers 
the prospect of retirement. What if someone else donned
the coral crown so he could spend his immortality
harmonizing with blue whales and cozying up to hydrothermal vents? Poseidon decides he needs to actually
prioritize himself for once. So he summons his accountant and asks: how much could he sell
the ocean for today? Poseidon’s accountant is the
top-ranked financial analyst to the world’s movers and shakers, its literal titans of industry. He handles all divine assets. When it comes to boiling complex systems
of intrinsic value down to monetary sums, he’s the guy. And he’s actually got a potential buyer: Hades is interested in building
his real estate portfolio and expanding his domain
into the marine realm. So, the accountant already appraised
the ocean’s market value and prepared a quick presentation. "The property covers
over 70% of Earth’s surface. But it’s also quite voluminous!" Poseidon knows this. He does annual Mariana Trench
swims with sea cucumbers. But before he even gets
to his best giant squid story, the accountant is back at analysis. "Marine shipping alone accounts
for 80% of global trade, generating over $14 trillion annually. The global fishing industry 
provides over 3 billion people with a significant amount 
of their dietary protein, employs an estimated 260 million, and generates about $163 billion
every year. And oil and budding
seabed mining industries generate around $245 billion per year." "Some of the ocean’s assets
are harder to quantify monetarily. The ocean absorbs around 30%
of human generated carbon dioxide, and, since 1955, has taken
in more than 90% of excess heat. About 40% of humanity lives
within 100 kilometers of the ocean. Coastal ecosystems buffer waves,
reduce erosion, and ease flooding, preventing over $716 billion
in damages annually. Many cultures have deep ties to the ocean. And coastal views and recreation
improve mental health. Meanwhile, it's estimated
that as-yet undiscovered marine-derived cancer treatments
could save countless lives and be worth up to $5.7 trillion. The ocean generates half
the planet’s oxygen and, directly or indirectly, provides food, energy, and minerals
to all life on Earth." A salty tear cascades down Poseidon’s face
that the accountant ignores. He can’t give the total cost yet
because, of course, recent developments must be factored in. "Climate change is heating, acidifying,
and deoxygenating the ocean and trash is polluting it. Overfishing and aggressive 
seabed resource extraction are disrupting fragile ecosystems
and impacting the ocean’s productivity." The accountant says, "Sigh, buddy,
you shouldn’t worry, though, because we can grow
the ocean’s investment value. Coral reef tourism already yields
approximately $36 billion annually. Considering the revenue
of popular dive sites and their regional shark
populations and lifespans, researchers estimate that one shark can
generate almost $2 million in its lifetime— making them much more valuable
alive than dead. Sustainable management of fisheries
could allow species to rebound and bring in an additional
$83 billion annually. And with growth in offshore wind, 
tidal, and wave energy harvesting, the ocean is poised to help
humanity quit fossil fuels." Now the grand reveal. The accountant's conclusions are similar
to those of mortal experts: the ocean alone is worth
roughly $24 trillion— at least— about a quarter
of the World Bank’s valuation of the global economy in 2021. But if humanity reinvests
in the ocean's health— fishing sustainably,
decarbonizing shipping, scaling offshore wind farms,
and conserving and restoring mangroves— investments could return
up to 600% in profits. Poseidon feels the weight of his folly
crushing him like a Styrofoam cup 2,000 meters deep. Reducing such a priceless, generously
life-giving natural system to a number is just another symptom of the greatest
problems he’s facing nowadays. And though he respects the work
his brother, Hades, does, he doesn't want the ocean to become
an extension of the Underworld. He can’t give it up. Poseidon asks forgiveness and reaffirms his eternal vow
to protect the ocean. It’ll take him a few tidal cycles
to realize Hades and the accountant were bluffing 
and see what this really was: a much-needed intervention by a duo
of deities who cared deeply about him— and the world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The ocean supplies ___ of our oxygen.
Options: A. 30%, B. 50%, C. 70%, D. 90%
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you were to place all the rice consumed
each year on one side of a scale, and every person in the world
on the other, the scale would tip heavily
towards rice's favor. This beloved crop contributes over 20% of
the calories consumed by humans each year. Korean bibimbap, Nigerian jollof,
Indian biryani, Spanish paella, and countless other culinary masterpieces
all begin with rice. So how did this humble grain
end up in so many cuisines? The roots of rice go back thousands
of years to when early farmers in Asia, Africa, and South America
each independently domesticated the crop. First came Asian rice, which many plant geneticists believe
originated in what's now China. Over 10,000 years ago,
nomadic hunters in the region began gathering and eating seeds
from a weedy grass. Then, around 9,000 years ago,
they started planting these seeds, prompting nomadic hunters to settle
into farming communities. With each harvest, growers selected
and replanted seeds from the rice plants
that pleased them most— like those with bigger and more plentiful
grains or aromatic flavors. Over millennia, thousands of varieties
of Asian rice emerged. A relative of the same weedy grass
was also domesticated in Africa around 3,000 years ago. Today, its growth is mostly limited
to West Africa. South American growers also domesticated
rice around 4,000 years ago, though the crop was lost
after the arrival of Europeans. Asian rice, however, spread widely, and is now a cornerstone of diet
and culture in Asia and beyond. In India and Nepal, many Hindus mark
an infant's transition to solid foods with a ceremony known as Annaprashan, where the baby tastes rice
for the first time. in Japan, rice is so central to diets
that the word "gohan" means both "cooked rice" and "meal." The global expansion of rice cultivation
was only possible because the plant can grow
in many climates— from tropical to temperate. As a semi-aquatic plant, rice happily
grows in submerged soils. Many other crops can't survive
in standing water because their root cells rely on air
within soil to access oxygen. But rice plants have air channels
in their roots that allow oxygen to travel from the leaves and stems
to the submerged tissues. Traditionally, growers plant
rice in paddy fields— flat land submerged under as much
as 10 centimeters of water throughout the growing season. This practice returns high yields
since many competing weeds can't hack it in the aquatic environment. But the technique is also water intensive. Rice covers 11% of global cropland, but uses over a third
of the world's irrigation water. This form of rice production
also pumps out a surprising amount
of greenhouse gas emissions. Flooded fields are the perfect breeding
grounds for microorganisms known as methanogens. These microscopic lifeforms thrive
in environments lacking oxygen, because they evolved when the Earth
contained little of this gas. Methanogens are the only organisms
known to produce methane— a greenhouse gas 25 times more potent
than carbon dioxide at trapping heat in the atmosphere. Cows, for example, are infamous
for burping out methane due to methanogens in their stomachs. In a flooded paddy field, methanogens set
to work eating away at organic material in the submerged soil
and multiplying rapidly, all the while releasing copious amounts
of methane. The result: rice cultivation
contributes around 12% of human-caused methane
emissions each year. But there's good news. Rice doesn't actually need to grow
in continuously flooded paddies. Researchers and growers are exploring
water management strategies that can cut the methane
while keeping the yield. One promising technique is known
as alternate wetting and drying. Growers periodically let
the water level drop, which keeps methanogen growth in check. Alternate wetting and drying
can cut water use by 30% and methane emissions
by 30 to 70% without impacting yield. Greenhouse gases come from many—
sometimes unexpected— places. Making rice growing more sustainable
is just one of the many challenges we'll need to face
to avoid catastrophic warming. Today, many rice growers still
flood fields all season long. Changing millennia-old practices
requires a major mindset shift. But going against the grain could be
just what we need to keep our planet healthy
and our bowls full.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of calories consumed by humans each year comes from rice?
Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 30%, D. 40%
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the calories consumed by humans each year is contributed by rice? Options: A. 15%, B. 20%, C. 25%, D. 30% Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following statements about the domestication of rice is true? Options: A. It occurred independently in Asia, Africa, and South America around 10,000 years ago., B. It occurred in Asia around 9,000 years ago., C. It occurred in Africa around 3,000 years ago., D. It occurred in South America around 4,000 years ago. Correct Option: A
Question 3: In India and Nepal, what ceremony marks an infant's transition to solid foods with a taste of rice for the first time? Options: A. Annaprashan, B. Gohan, C. Paddy, D. Harvest Correct Option: A
Question 4: What unique feature of the root system of rice plants allows them to grow in submerged soils? Options: A. They use air within the soil to access oxygen., B. They have air channels in their roots that allow oxygen to travel from the leaves and stems to the submerged tissues., C. They produce methane., D. They use specialized roots that can absorb oxygen from the water. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the name of the technique used to reduce water use and methane emissions in rice cultivation? Options: A. Alternate wetting and drying, B. Flooded fields, C. Paddy fields, D. Methanogens Correct Option: A
Question 6: What greenhouse gas is produced by methanogens in flooded paddy fields? Options: A. Carbon dioxide, B. Methane, C. Oxygen, D. Nitrogen Correct Option: B
Question 7: What percentage of human-caused methane emissions each year is contributed by rice cultivation? Options: A. 10%, B. 12%, C. 15%, D. 20% Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the potential impact of using alternate wetting and drying in rice cultivation? Options: A. It can increase water use by 30% and methane emissions by 30 to 70%., B. It can cut water use by 30% and methane emissions by 30 to 70%., C. It can have no impact on water use and methane emissions., D. It can increase yield by 30%. Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why is changing the traditional method of rice cultivation challenging? Options: A. Because it requires a lot of water., B. Because it requires a major mindset shift., C. Because it is not profitable., D. Because it is not sustainable. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the potential consequence of not addressing the challenges of rice cultivation? Options: A. It will lead to an increase in food production., B. It will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions., C. It will lead to catastrophic warming., D. It will have no impact on the environment. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: What percentage of the calories consumed by humans each year is contributed by rice? Options: A. 15%, B. 20%, C. 25%, D. 30% Correct Option: B**

This question has the same intent and content as the ground truth MCQ, with similar options. The correct option in both questions is 20% (B).

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **1**

can cut water use by 30% and methane emissions
by 30 to 70% without impacting yield. Greenhouse gases come from many—
sometimes unexpected— places. Making rice growing more sustainable
is just one of the many challenges we'll need to face
to avoid catastrophic warming. Today, many rice growers still
flood fields all season long. Changing millennia-old practices
requires a major mindset shift. But going against the grain could be
just what we need to keep our planet healthy
and our bowls full.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 3

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the percentage of global cropland covered by rice cultivation?
Options: A. 11%, B. 21%, C. 14%, D. 44%
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the calories consumed by humans each year is contributed by rice? Options: A. 15%, B. 20%, C. 25%, D. 30% Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following statements about the domestication of rice is true? Options: A. It occurred independently in Asia, Africa, and South America around 10,000 years ago., B. It occurred in Asia around 9,000 years ago., C. It occurred in Africa around 3,000 years ago., D. It occurred in South America around 4,000 years ago. Correct Option: A
Question 3: In India and Nepal, what ceremony marks an infant's transition to solid foods with a taste of rice for the first time? Options: A. Annaprashan, B. Gohan, C. Paddy, D. Harvest Correct Option: A
Question 4: What unique feature of the root system of rice plants allows them to grow in submerged soils? Options: A. They use air within the soil to access oxygen., B. They have air channels in their roots that allow oxygen to travel from the leaves and stems to the submerged tissues., C. They produce methane., D. They use specialized roots that can absorb oxygen from the water. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the name of the technique used to reduce water use and methane emissions in rice cultivation? Options: A. Alternate wetting and drying, B. Flooded fields, C. Paddy fields, D. Methanogens Correct Option: A
Question 6: What greenhouse gas is produced by methanogens in flooded paddy fields? Options: A. Carbon dioxide, B. Methane, C. Oxygen, D. Nitrogen Correct Option: B
Question 7: What percentage of human-caused methane emissions each year is contributed by rice cultivation? Options: A. 10%, B. 12%, C. 15%, D. 20% Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the potential impact of using alternate wetting and drying in rice cultivation? Options: A. It can increase water use by 30% and methane emissions by 30 to 70%., B. It can cut water use by 30% and methane emissions by 30 to 70%., C. It can have no impact on water use and methane emissions., D. It can increase yield by 30%. Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why is changing the traditional method of rice cultivation challenging? Options: A. Because it requires a lot of water., B. Because it requires a major mindset shift., C. Because it is not profitable., D. Because it is not sustainable. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the potential consequence of not addressing the challenges of rice cultivation? Options: A. It will lead to an increase in food production., B. It will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions., C. It will lead to catastrophic warming., D. It will have no impact on the environment. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 1 is not the most similar, as it is about the percentage of calories consumed by humans each year, not the percentage of global cropland covered by rice cultivation.**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you were to place all the rice consumed
each year on one side of a scale, and every person in the world
on the other, the scale would tip heavily
towards rice's favor. This beloved crop contributes over 20% of
the calories consumed by humans each year. Korean bibimbap, Nigerian jollof,
Indian biryani, Spanish paella, and countless other culinary masterpieces
all begin with rice. So how did this humble grain
end up in so many cuisines? The roots of rice go back thousands
of years to when early farmers in Asia, Africa, and South America
each independently domesticated the crop. First came Asian rice, which many plant geneticists believe
originated in what's now China. Over 10,000 years ago,
nomadic hunters in the region began gathering and eating seeds
from a weedy grass. Then, around 9,000 years ago,
they started planting these seeds, prompting nomadic hunters to settle
into farming communities. With each harvest, growers selected
and replanted seeds from the rice plants
that pleased them most— like those with bigger and more plentiful
grains or aromatic flavors. Over millennia, thousands of varieties
of Asian rice emerged. A relative of the same weedy grass
was also domesticated in Africa around 3,000 years ago. Today, its growth is mostly limited
to West Africa. South American growers also domesticated
rice around 4,000 years ago, though the crop was lost
after the arrival of Europeans. Asian rice, however, spread widely, and is now a cornerstone of diet
and culture in Asia and beyond. In India and Nepal, many Hindus mark
an infant's transition to solid foods with a ceremony known as Annaprashan, where the baby tastes rice
for the first time. in Japan, rice is so central to diets
that the word "gohan" means both "cooked rice" and "meal." The global expansion of rice cultivation
was only possible because the plant can grow
in many climates— from tropical to temperate. As a semi-aquatic plant, rice happily
grows in submerged soils. Many other crops can't survive
in standing water because their root cells rely on air
within soil to access oxygen. But rice plants have air channels
in their roots that allow oxygen to travel from the leaves and stems
to the submerged tissues. Traditionally, growers plant
rice in paddy fields— flat land submerged under as much
as 10 centimeters of water throughout the growing season. This practice returns high yields
since many competing weeds can't hack it in the aquatic environment. But the technique is also water intensive. Rice covers 11% of global cropland, but uses over a third
of the world's irrigation water. This form of rice production
also pumps out a surprising amount
of greenhouse gas emissions. Flooded fields are the perfect breeding
grounds for microorganisms known as methanogens. These microscopic lifeforms thrive
in environments lacking oxygen, because they evolved when the Earth
contained little of this gas. Methanogens are the only organisms
known to produce methane— a greenhouse gas 25 times more potent
than carbon dioxide at trapping heat in the atmosphere. Cows, for example, are infamous
for burping out methane due to methanogens in their stomachs. In a flooded paddy field, methanogens set
to work eating away at organic material in the submerged soil
and multiplying rapidly, all the while releasing copious amounts
of methane. The result: rice cultivation
contributes around 12% of human-caused methane
emissions each year. But there's good news. Rice doesn't actually need to grow
in continuously flooded paddies. Researchers and growers are exploring
water management strategies that can cut the methane
while keeping the yield. One promising technique is known
as alternate wetting and drying. Growers periodically let
the water level drop, which keeps methanogen growth in check. Alternate wetting and drying
can cut water use by 30% and methane emissions
by 30 to 70% without impacting yield. Greenhouse gases come from many—
sometimes unexpected— places. Making rice growing more sustainable
is just one of the many challenges we'll need to face
to avoid catastrophic warming. Today, many rice growers still
flood fields all season long. Changing millennia-old practices
requires a major mindset shift. But going against the grain could be
just what we need to keep our planet healthy
and our bowls full.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What fraction of human-caused methane emissions is contributed by rice cultivation each year?
Options: A. 5%, B. 8%, C. 12%, D. 18%
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the calories consumed by humans each year is contributed by rice? Options: A. 15%, B. 20%, C. 25%, D. 30% Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following statements about the domestication of rice is true? Options: A. It occurred independently in Asia, Africa, and South America around 10,000 years ago., B. It occurred in Asia around 9,000 years ago., C. It occurred in Africa around 3,000 years ago., D. It occurred in South America around 4,000 years ago. Correct Option: A
Question 3: In India and Nepal, what ceremony marks an infant's transition to solid foods with a taste of rice for the first time? Options: A. Annaprashan, B. Gohan, C. Paddy, D. Harvest Correct Option: A
Question 4: What unique feature of the root system of rice plants allows them to grow in submerged soils? Options: A. They use air within the soil to access oxygen., B. They have air channels in their roots that allow oxygen to travel from the leaves and stems to the submerged tissues., C. They produce methane., D. They use specialized roots that can absorb oxygen from the water. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the name of the technique used to reduce water use and methane emissions in rice cultivation? Options: A. Alternate wetting and drying, B. Flooded fields, C. Paddy fields, D. Methanogens Correct Option: A
Question 6: What greenhouse gas is produced by methanogens in flooded paddy fields? Options: A. Carbon dioxide, B. Methane, C. Oxygen, D. Nitrogen Correct Option: B
Question 7: What percentage of human-caused methane emissions each year is contributed by rice cultivation? Options: A. 10%, B. 12%, C. 15%, D. 20% Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the potential impact of using alternate wetting and drying in rice cultivation? Options: A. It can increase water use by 30% and methane emissions by 30 to 70%., B. It can cut water use by 30% and methane emissions by 30 to 70%., C. It can have no impact on water use and methane emissions., D. It can increase yield by 30%. Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why is changing the traditional method of rice cultivation challenging? Options: A. Because it requires a lot of water., B. Because it requires a major mindset shift., C. Because it is not profitable., D. Because it is not sustainable. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the potential consequence of not addressing the challenges of rice cultivation? Options: A. It will lead to an increase in food production., B. It will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions., C. It will lead to catastrophic warming., D. It will have no impact on the environment. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the fraction of human-caused methane emissions contributed by rice cultivation each year. The options are also similar, with the correct option being 12% in both cases.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7.

since many competing weeds can't hack it in the aquatic environment. But the technique is also water intensive. Rice covers 11% of global cropland, but uses over a third

also pumps out a surprising amount

grounds for microorganisms known as methanogens. These microscopic lifeforms thrive

while keeping the yield. One promising technique is known
as alternate wetting and drying. Growers periodically let

can cut water use by 30% and methane emissions
by 30 to 70% without impacting yield. Greenhouse gases come from many—
sometimes unexpected— places. Making rice growing more sustainable
is just one of the many challenges we'll need to face
to avoid catastrophic warming. Today, many rice growers still
flood fields all season long. Changing millennia-old practices
requires a major mindset shift. But going against the grain could be
just what we need to keep our planet healthy
and our bowls full.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. 40%, B. 50%, C. 20%, D. 30%
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the late 1930s, a grand panda drama
unfolded at the Chicago Zoo. Su-Lin, who had been a media darling
since she was a cub, passed away. Zookeepers were already in the process of procuring another female panda
named Mei Mei, and they were determined to find her
a mate before tragedy struck again. So when they acquired a prospective suitor
named Mei Lan, it seemed their troubles were over. Magazines monitored their progress, and the public eagerly awaited
the patter of tiny panda paws. But the wait dragged on. At first, headlines declared that Mei Mei
was "getting nowhere" with her love life. But eventually zookeepers realized
their significant slip-up: both bears were male. This is just one of many mistakes humans
have made when it comes to pandas. We've incorrectly classified
them as raccoons, misrepresented them as cuddly vegetarians, and— since the doomed union
of Mei Mei and Mei Lan— declared them as incompetent lovers. Some people have taken this even further, suggesting it's remarkable
this sex-shy species has been able to sustain
themselves at all. However, this common perception of pandas
having low libidos actually has more to do
with human incompetence. When it comes to breeding pandas
in captivity, zookeepers face multiple challenges. As the Chicago case suggests, it can be
tricky to figure out a panda's sex. Their external genitals don't appear
until they're a few months old, and once visible, they look very similar. This forces zookeepers to rely
on inconsistent methods, like trying to measure the distance
between the anus and genitals, or simply going by feel. And even when males and females
are paired up correctly, chemistry isn't guaranteed. In one case at the Moscow Zoo, a female bear that had been isolated
from other animals proved more interested in zookeepers
than other pandas. Complicating things further, female pandas can only be impregnated
1 to 3 days each year due to their incredibly short
ovulation window. Zookeepers try to track fertility levels
by measuring the hormones in their urine, but this data is often cryptic to decipher
and messy to capture. Females have also evolved the ability
to reabsorb their own fetuses, meaning that even a successful
impregnation can be reversed. The difficulty of breeding pandas
has reinforced the idea that they're not naturally
inclined to procreate. But there's a huge gap between how these
animals behave in captivity and the privacy of the wild. Prowling through her home territory, a female panda rubs her anal glands
on tree trunks to attract mates, then waits in the treetops
bleating as loudly as she can. Soon enough, males crowd around the tree
and compete for her attention by seeing who can pee the highest. Suitors adopt a variety of poses
in these competitions, including the "squat," "legcock,"
and "handstand." They're also known to dab urine
behind their ears to broadcast their virility
through the breeze. Once a female picks a winner, the mating pair will often have sex
over 40 times in a single afternoon. At these rates, you might expect
panda populations to be booming, especially since panda sperm
is incredibly potent. But females' short ovulation cycles
and ability to reabsorb fetuses keep the population in check. In the wild, young pandas are usually able
to witness at least one breeding season before reaching sexual maturity, giving them time to learn
the rituals of seduction. But in captivity, pandas are never
able to learn these customs. And while breeders have tried to kick
start young pandas' sexual awakenings by showing them footage of mating elders
and offering them doses of Viagra, none of these strategies have
worked consistently. The most reliable approach they've
found is artificial insemination, which has dramatically increased
the captive population in the past few decades. But if pandas are so much better
at reproducing in the wild, one has to ask why are conservation
efforts so focused on breeding them. Maybe our time would be better spent protecting the pandas'
natural environments, giving them all the space they need
to get down to business.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why were Mei Mei and Mei Lan unsuccessful mates at the Chicago Zoo?
Options: A. Mei Mei was not fertile., B. Mei Mei and Mei Lan did not care for each other., C. Both Mei Mei and Mei Lan were male., D. The zoo environment was not conducive to mating. 
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of the female panda that passed away at the Chicago Zoo in the late 1930s? Options: A. Mei Mei, B. Su-Lin, C. Mei Lan, D. Mei Xiang Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what was the initial problem with the union of Mei Mei and Mei Lan at the Chicago Zoo? Options: A. Mei Mei was not interested in Mei Lan., B. Mei Lan was too young., C. Both bears were male., D. Mei Mei was not compatible with Mei Lan. Correct Option: C
Question 3: In the wild, how do female pandas typically attract mates? Options: A. By vocalizing loudly from the treetops., B. By rubbing their anal glands on tree trunks., C. By competing with males in urine-marking competitions., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is a major challenge faced by zookeepers when trying to breed pandas in captivity? Options: A. Difficulty in determining the sex of pandas., B. Measuring the distance between the anus and genitals., C. Tracking fertility levels by measuring hormones in urine., D. Both A and B. Correct Option: A
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is a unique aspect of female pandas' reproductive biology? Options: A. They can only be impregnated 1 to 3 days each year., B. They can reabsorb their own fetuses., C. They have a long ovulation window., D. They can breed year-round. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a common misconception about pandas that has been perpetuated by humans? Options: A. They are naturally inclined to procreate., B. They have low libidos., C. They are incompetent lovers., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 7: In the wild, how many times can a female panda have sex with a male in a single afternoon? Options: A. 10 to 20 times., B. 20 to 30 times., C. 30 to 40 times., D. Over 40 times. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the most reliable approach that breeders have found to increase the captive panda population? Options: A. Artificial insemination., B. Showing young pandas footage of mating elders., C. Offering young pandas doses of Viagra., D. Trying to measure the distance between the anus and genitals. Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, why are conservation efforts focused on breeding pandas in captivity, despite their natural ability to reproduce in the wild? Options: A. Because breeding in captivity is more cost-effective., B. Because it allows for greater control over the breeding process., C. Because the pandas' natural environments are being destroyed., D. Because the captive panda population will increase. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a potential consequence of breeding pandas in captivity, rather than protecting their natural environments? Options: A. The captive panda population will increase., B. The wild panda population will decrease., C. The pandas will become more dependent on humans., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the reason why Mei Mei and Mei Lan were unsuccessful mates at the Chicago Zoo. The correct option in both questions is that both bears were male. The options in Question 2 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the main difference being the wording of the incorrect options. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the late 1930s, a grand panda drama
unfolded at the Chicago Zoo. Su-Lin, who had been a media darling
since she was a cub, passed away. Zookeepers were already in the process of procuring another female panda
named Mei Mei, and they were determined to find her

natural environments, giving them all the space they need
to get down to business.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Female pandas can only be impregnated ____ each year.
Options: A. 1-3 days, B. 1-3 weeks, C. 1-3 months, D. 1-3 times
Correct Option: A

Showing young pandas footage of mating elders., C. Offering young pandas doses of Viagra., D. Trying to measure the distance between the anus and genitals. Correct Option: A

Because breeding in captivity is more cost-effective., B. Because it allows for greater control over the breeding process., C. Because the pandas' natural environments are being destroyed., D. Because the captive panda population will increase. Correct Option: B

The wild panda population will decrease., C. The pandas will become more dependent on humans., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the late 1930s, a grand panda drama
unfolded at the Chicago Zoo. Su-Lin, who had been a media darling
since she was a cub, passed away. Zookeepers were already in the process of procuring another female panda
named Mei Mei, and they were determined to find her
a mate before tragedy struck again. So when they acquired a prospective suitor
named Mei Lan, it seemed their troubles were over. Magazines monitored their progress, and the public eagerly awaited
the patter of tiny panda paws. But the wait dragged on. At first, headlines declared that Mei Mei
was "getting nowhere" with her love life. But eventually zookeepers realized
their significant slip-up: both bears were male. This is just one of many mistakes humans
have made when it comes to pandas. We've incorrectly classified
them as raccoons, misrepresented them as cuddly vegetarians, and— since the doomed union
of Mei Mei and Mei Lan— declared them as incompetent lovers. Some people have taken this even further, suggesting it's remarkable
this sex-shy species has been able to sustain
themselves at all. However, this common perception of pandas
having low libidos actually has more to do
with human incompetence. When it comes to breeding pandas
in captivity, zookeepers face multiple challenges. As the Chicago case suggests, it can be
tricky to figure out a panda's sex. Their external genitals don't appear
until they're a few months old, and once visible, they look very similar. This forces zookeepers to rely
on inconsistent methods, like trying to measure the distance
between the anus and genitals, or simply going by feel. And even when males and females
are paired up correctly, chemistry isn't guaranteed. In one case at the Moscow Zoo, a female bear that had been isolated
from other animals proved more interested in zookeepers
than other pandas. Complicating things further, female pandas can only be impregnated
1 to 3 days each year due to their incredibly short
ovulation window. Zookeepers try to track fertility levels
by measuring the hormones in their urine, but this data is often cryptic to decipher
and messy to capture. Females have also evolved the ability
to reabsorb their own fetuses, meaning that even a successful
impregnation can be reversed. The difficulty of breeding pandas
has reinforced the idea that they're not naturally
inclined to procreate. But there's a huge gap between how these
animals behave in captivity and the privacy of the wild. Prowling through her home territory, a female panda rubs her anal glands
on tree trunks to attract mates, then waits in the treetops
bleating as loudly as she can. Soon enough, males crowd around the tree
and compete for her attention by seeing who can pee the highest. Suitors adopt a variety of poses
in these competitions, including the "squat," "legcock,"
and "handstand." They're also known to dab urine
behind their ears to broadcast their virility
through the breeze. Once a female picks a winner, the mating pair will often have sex
over 40 times in a single afternoon. At these rates, you might expect
panda populations to be booming, especially since panda sperm
is incredibly potent. But females' short ovulation cycles
and ability to reabsorb fetuses keep the population in check. In the wild, young pandas are usually able
to witness at least one breeding season before reaching sexual maturity, giving them time to learn
the rituals of seduction. But in captivity, pandas are never
able to learn these customs. And while breeders have tried to kick
start young pandas' sexual awakenings by showing them footage of mating elders
and offering them doses of Viagra, none of these strategies have
worked consistently. The most reliable approach they've
found is artificial insemination, which has dramatically increased
the captive population in the past few decades. But if pandas are so much better
at reproducing in the wild, one has to ask why are conservation
efforts so focused on breeding them. Maybe our time would be better spent protecting the pandas'
natural environments, giving them all the space they need
to get down to business.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a common misconception about pandas?
Options: A. They often reabsorb their fetuses during pregnancy., B. They are not naturally inclined to procreate., C. Their fertility is difficult to track., D. All of the above.
Correct Option: B

Question 5: According to the transcript, what is a unique aspect of female pandas' reproductive biology? Options: A. They can only be impregnated 1 to 3 days each year., B. They can reabsorb their own fetuses., C. They have a long ovulation window., D. They can breed year-round. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is a common misconception about pandas that has been perpetuated by humans? Options: A. They are naturally inclined to procreate., B. They have low libidos., C. They are incompetent lovers., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D
Question 7: In the wild, how many times can a female panda have sex with a male in a single afternoon? Options: A. 10 to 20 times., B. 20 to 30 times., C. 30 to 40 times., D. Over 40 times. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the most reliable approach that breeders have found to increase the captive panda population? Options: A. Artificial insemination., B. Showing young pandas footage of mating elders., C. Offering young pandas doses of Viagra., D. Trying to measure the distance between the anus and genitals. Correct Option: A
Question 9: According to the transcript, why are conservation efforts focused on breeding pandas in captivity, despite their natural ability to reproduce in the wild? Options: A. Because breeding in captivity is more cost-effective., B. Because it allows for greater control over the breeding process., C. Because the pandas' natural environments are being destroyed., D. Because the captive panda population will increase. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a potential consequence of breeding pandas in captivity, rather than protecting their natural environments? Options: A. The captive panda population will increase., B. The wild panda population will decrease., C. The pandas will become more dependent on humans., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about a common misconception about pandas. The options provided in Question 6 also align with the ground truth MCQ, specifically option B in the ground truth MCQ ("They are not naturally inclined to procreate") is related to option B in Question 6 ("They have low libidos") and option C in Question 6 ("They are incompetent lovers"). 

Although the wording is not identical, the overall content and intent of Question 6 make it the most similar to the ground truth MCQ.

In the late 1930s, a grand panda drama
unfolded at the Chicago Zoo. Su-Lin, who had been a media darling
since she was a cub, passed away. Zookeepers were already in the process of procuring another female panda
named Mei Mei, and they were determined to find her
a mate before tragedy struck again. So when they acquired a prospective suitor

the patter of tiny panda paws. But the wait dragged on. At first, headlines declared that Mei Mei

have made when it comes to pandas. We've incorrectly classified
them as raccoons, misrepresented them as cuddly vegetarians, and— since the doomed union
of Mei Mei and Mei Lan— declared them as incompetent lovers. Some people have taken this even further, suggesting it's remarkable
this sex-shy species has been able to sustain
themselves at all. However, this common perception of pandas
having low libidos actually has more to do

in captivity, zookeepers face multiple challenges. As the Chicago case suggests, it can be

from other animals proved more interested in zookeepers
than other pandas. Complicating things further, female pandas can only be impregnated
1 to 3 days each year due to their incredibly short
ovulation window. Zookeepers try to track fertility levels
by measuring the hormones in their urine, but this data is often cryptic to decipher
and messy to capture. Females have also evolved the ability
to reabsorb their own fetuses, meaning that even a successful
impregnation can be reversed. The difficulty of breeding pandas
has reinforced the idea that they're not naturally
inclined to procreate. But there's a huge gap between how these
animals behave in captivity and the privacy of the wild. Prowling through her home territory, a female panda rubs her anal glands
on tree trunks to attract mates, then waits in the treetops

at reproducing in the wild, one has to ask why are conservation
efforts so focused on breeding them. Maybe our time would be better spent protecting the pandas'
natural environments, giving them all the space they need
to get down to business.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why is it difficult to breed pandas in captivity?
Options: A. It is challenging to determine a panda's sex., B. Females have short ovulation periods., C. Captive pandas are not able to witness a breeding season before mating., D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

named Mei Mei, and they were determined to find her

have made when it comes to pandas. We've incorrectly classified

natural environments, giving them all the space they need
to get down to business.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Showing pandas footage of mating elders, B. Dosing mating pandas with Viagra, C. Artificial insemination, D. Recreating natural environments in captivity
Correct Option: C
